title: Relief in the City but pound falls back after Scotland rejects independence - business live | Business | The Guardian
summary: cbi warns uk must work to restore trust .
s & p : no impact on uk credit rating .
gsk to pay £ 297m over bribery scandal .
ftse 100 up 51 points at the open .
standard life : we 'll keep building on scottish roots .

text: the guardian ( @ guardian ) ftse 100 finishes marginally higher as scottish vote boost runs out of steam

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: well , we 've seen more impressive rallies , frankly .
this was a day of mild relief in the city , rather than full-blown jubilation .
despite all the warnings from business leaders and economists before yesterday 's vote , the stock rally largely fizzled out by the finish .
the london stock market has just closed for the day , with the ftse 100 index gaining a mere18 points to 6837 .
scottish-based firms have performed well , with royal bank of scotland jumping 2.5 % after the risk that it would have to relocate its head office to london vanished .
here 's nick fletcher 's closing market report , explaining how the rally ran out of steam .
ftse 100 biggest risers tonight .
reuters ftse 100 over the last quarter .
reuters jasper lawler of cmc markets says that a no victory was priced in .
thus no big rally .
shares in europe breathed a big sigh of relief on the news one of its member countries did n't split apart as the scottish vote no '' to independence from the uk .
the scottish referendum was largely anticipated by stock markets and given the risks associated with a separation the argument could be made that investors were almost complacent .
the pound has also lost its early gains , and is now down almost one cent against the us dollar since the polls closed , at $ 1.632 .

that 's partly because the dollar is generally strong today , as brenda kelly of ig index explains : sterling 's relief rally against the us dollar was even more short-lived than the 'yes ' camp 's hope of victory in scotland last night .
having touched $ 1.65 , the pound is now in retreat , dropping back down towards $ 1.63 as economic fundamentals reassert themselves .
investors also welcomed the fact that britain does n't face months of argument between westminster and holyrood ahead of a formal declaration of independence .
but attention is now turning to other political uncertainties , especially with alex salmond resigning a few minutes ago .
live : salmond to resign as first minister after scotland rejects independence many economists have warned today that political uncertainty is going to weigh on the uk economy .

for example : gregor macintosh , of swiss bank lombard odier believes investors will demand a higher risk premium for uk assets jon pryor of investec has warned that next year 's general election could cause market uncertainty .
stephen lewis of adm investor services fears that new agreement on devolved powers will not be agreed easily , or quickly .
and hsbc predicted that the pound could be hit if uk growth or trade figures disappoint .
and the scottish result dominated global politics as well as finance today .
the was relief in brussels , with ec president jose manuel barroso saying that it 's good news for europe .

barroso added : the european commission welcomes the fact that during the debate over the past years , the scottish government and the scottish people have repeatedly reaffirmed their european commitment .

the european commission will continue to engage in a constructive dialogue with the scottish government , in areas under its responsibility , that are important to scotland 's future , including jobs and growth , energy , climate change and the environment , and smarter regulation .
fitch and s & p have both announced that the result has no impact on the uk credit rating .
bute house in edinburgh where scottish first minister alex salmond has resigned .
lawson/pa while in scotland itself , financial workers told us they were relieved but yes supporters were understandably disappointed .
angus kirk , a director at wealth management company bridge investments partners , summed up the mood in the no camp : now it 's as rbs said this morning , business as usual very much . ''
a no result was always going to be the best result for scotland because scotland will get more powers , be stronger and not lose its identity . ''
but at an edinburgh job centre , alex clough explained why he voted for independence : it was more just disillusionment with the people in government down in westminster .
it might end up the same up here but i felt like i would have been a hyprocrite to complain and not vote yes . ''

the organisation for economic co-operation and development , the paris-based thinktank , has weighed in on the scottish referendum - welcoming both the result and the huge turnout for a ballot that caught the eyes of the world .
oecd secretary-general angel gurría said : the choice of the scottish people to remain part of the united kingdom is good news for scotland , for the uk and for the world .
the fact that the scots came out to vote in such huge numbers is the sign of a thriving and healthy democracy . ''

documents.title: cbi warns uk must work to restore trust
text: a supporter of the yes '' campaign in george square today .

mcnaughton/reuters katja hall , deputy director-general of the business group cbi - which openly and vocally opposed scottish independence - says the uk has its work cut out to restore trust from foreign investors and trade partners after the referendum .
speaking to my colleague katie allen , hall warned : we have got a job now to do to rebuild our international reputation .
people have been looking at what is happening and have been worried .
lots of investment has been on pause so hopefully that can start to get going again . ''
hall says the group 's members saw the referendum on scottish independence as the biggest uncertainty they faced and will be generally pleased it is now over .
i think businesses will be very relieved and breathe a collective sigh of relief at the outcome .
we have always said staying together was the best thing to do for jobs , for growth and for living standards . ''
as for what comes next , she adds : we want a devolution settlement that is good for growth across he uk .
we must not be kneejerk , we need considered and thought out proposals .
it ca n't be a free for all . ''
hall , whose organisation supports staying in a reformed european union '' , was encouraged by the high turnout for this week 's vote .
if we have a referendum on the uk 's membership of the eu we hope to see people as engaged as on scotland . ''
garry clark , at the scottish chambers of commerce , has also emphasised the uncertainties that remain for businesses in scotland .
the scc remained impartial during the campaign , recognising that the 11,000 businesses in its network had varying views .
but canvassing showed they shared key concerns around scotland 's future currency , tax policy and eu membership .
clark points out only the first of those three was resolved as scotland woke up to a no vote .
there remain issues over what the future tax environment in scotland looks like and also now there is perhaps slightly greater chance of an eu referendum in three years ' time .
our members want to be in the eu . ''

but generally , scotland 's economy is gaining momentum after faster growth than the rest of the uk as it went into this year , lower unemployment in the latest figures and strong inward investment , he says .
we are very optimistic , '' says clark .
and here 's legal expert joshua rozenberg explaining why blocking scottish mps from voting on english issues is so controversial ; a potential source of future market volatility perhaps .
the guardian ( @ guardian ) west lothian question : easy to ask , trickier to answer
westminster bridge , by the houses of parliament , today .
arrizabalaga/epa next may 's general election , and a possible referendum on britain 's membership of the eu , mean we could see further market turbulence .

so reckons jon pryor , head of fx dealing , investec corporate and institutional treasury , who says : this morning 's relief rally for sterling after scotland voted to remain in the uk should see a conclusion to the recent high volatility environment in the short term .
in the medium term there is more political event risk to come : the detail of meaningful constitutional change will be with us by january , just a few months before may 's general election .

should the conservatives win a clear majority then , a referendum on uk membership of the european union becomes inevitable based on prime minister cameron 's previous assertions , and this is before we consider the impact of a likely first rate hike in the coming months .
the potential catalyst for the next currency move can be difficult to predict but , as recent weeks have shown , markets can react strongly to the political calendar . ''

documents.title: larry elliott : questions remain despite scottish result
text: our economics editor , larry elliott , also warns that the upbeat mood in the city could soon evaporate .
he writes relief rather than euphoria .
that was the instant response in the financial markets to the scottish referendum vote .
relief that they had been spared months , perhaps years , of wrangling about what currency scotland might use .
relief that the risk of a bank run had been avoided .
relief that there was unlikely to be a flurry of announcements by companies that they were packing their bags .
relief , above all , that it was not going to be black friday .

but now we need to see whether the referendum question is really off the table for a generation , whether scotland 's business community has been hurt , and whether the no vote is likely to lead to an earlier rise in interest rates .
here 's the full piece : uk plc breathes easy again after scotland 's no vote - but for how long ?
the pound may be down a little bit today , but that 's nothing compared to the wild swings we 'd have seen if yesterday 's poll had swung the other way .
katie martin ( @ katie martin fx ) ask not why gbp is a tiny bit weaker on the day ( ans : profit taking ) , but instead where it would have been if it had been 'yes ' ( ans : gulp )
with the scottish referendum decided , the markets are now turning their attention to chinese e-commerce giant alibaba , which is floating on the us stock market today .
it 's a a genuinely huge deal , probably the biggest ipo ever .
my us colleague tom mccarthy is tracking the action : alibaba ipo : trading to begin as shares priced at $ 68 - live updates

over in the wall street journal , simon nixon argues that investors may not have woken up to the full impact of the shake-up in british politics : in particular , he cites the pledge for more devolution to scotland , and david cameron 's promise this morning to tackle the west lothian question '' and restrict voting on 'english issues ' to english mps .
nixon writes : far from settling the debate over the u.k. constitution , the scottish referendum has taken the debate to a whole new level .

mr. cameron 's commitment , hastily given without the agreement of his cabinet or his party , has already prompted an angry backlash from english and welsh parliamentarians demanding new rights for their voters .
the markets may have greeted the referendum result with relief , but they may be underestimating the risk of serious political instability in the u.k. in the months and years ahead .
that would also help explain why the pound is now down on the day simon nixon ( @ simon nixon ) far from settling uk constitutional debate , scottish referendum has taken it to a whole new level .
my blog .

documents.title: pound 's drop deepens
text: after that early rally , the pound is now down half a cent against the us dollar today at $ 1.635 .
that means all the referendum bounce has been wiped out , taking sterling back town to its level before the shock yougov poll two weekends ago .

this chart shows the pound vs the us dollar in september : pound vs us dollar , september 1-19th 2014 reuters stephen lewis of adm investor services reckons that the financial markets are recognising that the uk 's political affairs remain fluid .

it will be challenging for westminster political leaders to meet the timetable for further scottish devolution that mr gordon brown advanced , with their endorsement , during the referendum campaign .
with the best will in the world , they will be hard-pressed to comply with it .
a major risk is that they will not be able to agree the terms of a settlement , especially as the exercise will offer opportunities for points to be scored ahead of a general election .

the fallout of the referendum result is also unclear , lewis adds : it might be disastrous if a significant proportion of yesterday 's 'no ' voters were subsequently to feel they had been misled by the promises the westminster elite had made to them .

documents.title: kilt shop owner relieved that tourist trade wo n't suffer
text: edinburgh gifts allen scottish firms continue to digest the implications of the referendum result , reports katie allen from edinburgh .
callum kerr , part-owner of kilts shop edinburgh gifts thinks a yes vote would have been bad for tourism .

he says a majority of tourism in edinburgh comes from england and many of the other visitors that buy scarves , kilts and tweed jackets from his store are often on tours that start south of the border .
if we were an independent country things like that might not be possible , '' he says , adding most shop owners he asked on his stretch of souvenir stores felt the same in the run up to the vote .
the tourism industry is still growing and to break away and not be part of that would be worrying . ''
callum kerr .
allen

documents.title: investors could still see uk assets as riskier
text: the ftse 100 remains unspectacularly higher , up 38 points at 6857 , led by royal bank of scotland ( +3 % ) .

but gregor macintosh , head of sovereign and emerging debt at swiss private bank lombard odier , reckons that political uncertainty could hit uk financial markets soon : crucially we still have to worry about the prospect of major constitutional upheaval .
in these negotiations it is questionable whether cross-party co-ordination will be amicable .
particularly now that the referendum hurdle has passed and the glare of next year 's general election is intensifying .
this means that investors are still likely to demand a higher political risk premium in their valuation of uk assets .

guy ellison , head of equities at investec wealth & investment , says that the pound 's rally petered out because of the lack of clarity '' over the consequences of further devolution of powers to all uk regions .
it 's been a funny morning for the pound .
bleary-eyed traders drove sterling up once it became clear that scotland would vote to remain in the uk , only to push it down again once the result was confirmed .
pound vs us dollar , september 19 2014 reuters city insiders are citing a few reasons .
profit taking is one factor , after a day 's worth of sterling was traded between midnight and 2am .
another is the political uncertainty that remains , with pm david cameron promising a devolution shake-up after next may 's election .

analysts at hsbc says that attention is turning back to the uk 's economy : any disappointment on growth , or renewed focus on the large current account deficit , could still weigh on the currency . ''
and a fourth explanation is that the us dollar is strengthening generally , on predictions that american interest rates will rise quicker than expected in 2015 and 2016 .

fathom consultancy says : since the beginning of last year , £ / $ has been driven almost entirely by changing views about who would move first - the federal reserve or the bank of england - and by how much .
back in the financial sector , scottish-based businesses are outperforming the wider markets .
city firm banc de binary reports that shares in the 30 largest scottish firms are up 1.1 % , while the wider ftse 100 is only up 0.7 % ( 46 points ) now .

but that does n't make up for several months of underperformance during the independence campaign.. de binary this list includes major financial companies including rbs , energy firms such as premier oil , drinks firm ag barr , and distribution chain john menzies .

oren laurent , founder of banc de binary , reckons scottish shares have further to rally : the destabilising possibilities of a yes vote clearly made investors nervous , and this has affected the share price performance of scottish businesses and impacted the scottish economy . ''
with a no victory , the cloud that has been hanging over investors in businesses with a substantial scottish exposure has begun to lift .
however , it was never clear just how much independence would have actually affected performance of scottish businesses in the medium to long term . ''

documents.title: disillusionment at edinburgh job centre
text: allen just off edinburgh 's grand st andrew square , alex clough is coming out of a job centre .
he stayed up overnight with other friends who had voted yes until it became clear the no 's had won around 5am .
the 21-year-old graduated this summer from aberdeen university and has moved back in with his parents while he looks for work .
but his yes vote was not just down to the lack of jobs for graduates that he has discovered since leaving university .
clough tells katie allen : it was more just disillusionment with the people in government down in westminster .
it might end up the same up here but i felt like i would have been a hyprocrite to complain and not vote yes . ''
clough has been looking for graduate trainee schemes in consultancy or something related to his degree in zoology .
i am surprised there is not much for graduates , '' he says , adding he is now looking for non-graduate jobs in call centres and elsewhere .
( scroll back to 9.21am onwards for katie 's reporting of the mood in edinburgh )
back in edinburgh 's financial district , the mood is mixed with no supporters relieved and yes voters disappointed .
angus kirk , a director at wealth management company bridge investments partners , is in the former camp .
i am quite a relieved man this morning , '' kirk tells my colleague katie allen on his way into workthrough the drizzle .
now it 's as rbs said this morning , business as usual very much . ''
a no result was always going to be the best result for scotland because scotland will get more powers , be stronger and not lose its identity . ''
but he does not want to see any animosity .
no-one should be gloating about this at all , '' says kirk , who hails from edinburgh .
now is a time for reflection , in his view .
reflection for the country and on this historical event that hopefully wo n't happen again . ''
but it 's not all smiles of relief in st andrew square .
i am a bit disappointed with the result , '' says john , a public sector worker who does not want to give his surname .
i still think it is a lot of uncertainty with what happens next . ''

documents.title: chasing profits on the trading floors
text: traders at ig index look at screens on the trading floor after scotland 's independence referendum in central london september 19 , 2014 .
melville/reuters while it is quieter on the city 's trading floors than it would have been had the yes campaign triumphed , it is still a busy day as investors attempt to make - or take - profits .

from ig 's offices , simon goodley reports : hannah sissons , an equity trader at ig whose job it is to cap the group 's exposure if clients are betting heavily on a share price moving in one particular direction , says she is having a particularly busy morning .
more shares than normal have required her to dip into the market to hedge the company 's position .

meanwhile , her colleague ben critchley , a sales trader , reports that he has clients who warned him earlier this week that - in the event of a no vote - they wanted to have the first print '' [ the first orders ] to buy lloyds banking group shares .
the trades were placed this morning , meaning they got in at the day 's low before trading momentum took the price higher .
critchley adds : we also had a client who earlier this week - when the lloyds price was trading below 73p - who bought about 10 million shares in the hope of a no vote .

it was a punt , but it has worked out for him [ the price is nearer 77p now ] you can see from the screens that after the initial 10 minute surge in buy orders this morning , there are plenty of clients selling lloyds as they take their profit from trades they placed earlier this week . ''
and indeed , after jumping 2 % at the start of trading , lloyds shares are now up just over 1 % .

and here 's the official quote from fitch : scotland 's small share of the overall uk economy , and the relatively conservative limits set on scottish borrowing , mean that the fiscal risks posed by further scottish devolution are not high in our opinion . ''
steve collins , global head of dealing at london & capital asset management , says the pound is coming under pressure because the us dollar is strong today .
and also because traders had pushed sterling up overnight on anticipation that scotland would not choose independence .
steve collins ( @ tradedesk steve ) cable 160-tics off the high - a small part is the usd strength , overwhelming majority appears to be a classic buy the rumour sell the fac
the european council president tweets : herman van rompuy ( @ euhvr ) i respect , welcome choice of people of # scotland .
uk is important eu member , benefiting all citizens & member states :

documents.title: fitch : uk rating unaffected
text: a second rating agency , fitch has followed s & p by declaring that it wo n't be rethinking britain 's credit rating on the back of scottish developments .
importantly , fitch also says that the uncertainties over handing scotland more tax powers are relatively minor '' and not a key driver in its rating decision .
fitch downgraded the uk 18 months ago to aa+ ( the second-highest rating ) , with a stable outlook .
live squawk ( @ livesquawk ) fitch follow lead of s & p , say that potential scotland tax change does not threaten uk rating , fitch rate uk aa+ stable
gavin hewitt ( @ bbcgavinhewitt ) spanish pm rajoy - mindful of catalonia - says 'we are very happy scotland is staying with us ' .
calls it positive 'for integration of eu . '

documents.title: ec president welcomes scottish result
text: the prospect of scotland declaring independence had sent shivers through the corridors of power in brussels .
eurocrats feared that it would encourage more regions to seek autonomy , and raise the chances of britain leaving the european union .
so it 's no surprise that outgoing european commission president , jose manuel barroso , has welcomed the result .
barroso declared that the referendum result is good for europe : here 's the full statement : i welcome the decision of the scottish people to maintain the unity of the united kingdom .
this outcome is good for the united , open and stronger europe that the european commission stands for .
the european commission welcomes the fact that during the debate over the past years , the scottish government and the scottish people have repeatedly reaffirmed their european commitment .

the european commission will continue to engage in a constructive dialogue with the scottish government , in areas under its responsibility , that are important to scotland 's future , including jobs and growth , energy , climate change and the environment , and smarter regulation . ''
peter spiegel ( @ spiegelpeter ) .
@ barrosoeu has a hint of # brexit in # indyref statement : `` scottish govt & people repeatedly reaffirmed eu commitment ''

documents.title: s & p : no impact on uk credit rating
text: rating agency standard & poor 's has said that the scottish referendum will have no impact on the uk 's aaa credit rating .
s & p is the only one of the big three rating firms to still give the uk a triple-a rating , with a stable outlook .
hmmmm , the relief rally may be petering out , at least in the foreign exchange markets where the pound has given up this morning 's gains .
jill treanor ( @ jilltreanor ) sterling seems to be slipping a bit against the dollar - now at $ 1.6390 the ftse 100 is still up 50 points , though

and here 's proof that edinburgh worker jennifer telfer and her colleagues at recruitment firm eden scott are in upbeat mood this morning : sally rae , jennifer telfer and jamie armstrong from recruitment company eden scott allen
st andrew square in edinburgh this morning allen
edinburgh worker jennifer telfer is off to buy a celebratory coffee with colleagues who ca n't contain their excitement , even before katie allen can ask them what they make of the result .
they all work for recruitment consultancy eden scott , which has clients in the financial sector as well as oil and gas .

telfer , 26 , says : our business is dependent on the economy doing well and we have clients in scotland and england , '' she went home to the family farm in fife to vote yesterday and says shewas terrified '' about the outcome .
my dad is a farmer and sells most of his lamb and crops around the uk , into england and northern ireland .
why would we want to break that up . ''
my dad us not a landowner , he rents his farmland .
he is not full of money it would have been terrible for farmers . ''

documents.title: relief at st andrew square
text: people are arriving for work in edinburgh 's st andrew square , where several fund managers and other financial businesses are based , katie allen reports .
gary , who works in currency markets and only wants to give his first name , is relieved at the result of the referendum .
i was n't particularly strong on either side .
now we can just get on with business as usual .
the turmoil over the last two weeks , hopefully that will disappear now i 've been a busy bee . ''

he found the debate around the future currency of an independent scotland farcical '' : i really think alex salmond could have won the independence debate if he had had credible , detailed answers for the economic issues .
but he did n't , so he did n't '' george hay ( @ gfhay ) princes st , 8am : spontaneous no vote edinburgh street party not yet in evidence
back to scotland .
and all is very quiet in st. andrew square in edinburgh where many of the city 's financial institutions are based .

my colleague katie allen reports : while looking for workers to talk to on their way into offices , i have been chatting to economist ian kernohan at fund manager royal london asset management about what those new votes for english laws might mean for the uk government bond - or gilt - market .
kernohan tells me : markets had begun to price out the chance of a yes vote , so any impact of the result should be relatively muted , at least when compared with the alternative .

a move to english votes for english laws would introduce additional complexity into the uk political structure and might add an additional risk premium to gilt markets , given that the next government will still have to undertake a programme of fiscal consolidation .
at this stage though , the details on these plans are sketchy .

documents.title: gsk to pay £ 297m over bribery scandal
text: breaking away from scotland briefly , pharmaceuticals firm glaxosmithkline is to pay £ 297m to the chinese government over bribery charges .

the fine was imposed by the changsha intermediate people 's court in hunan province , which ruled that gsk china investment had offered money or property to non-government personnel in order to obtain improper commercial gains , and been found guilty of bribing non-government personnel .
gsk chief executive officer , sir andrew witty says : reaching a conclusion in the investigation of our chinese business is important , but this has been a deeply disappointing matter for gsk .
we have and will continue to learn from this .
gsk has been in china for close to a hundred years and we remain fully committed to the country and its people .
we will continue to expand access to innovative medicines and vaccines to improve their health and well-being .
we will also continue to invest directly in the country to support the government 's health care reform agenda and long-term plans for economic growth . ''
here 's the full statement .
dan milmo ( @ danmilmo ) glaxosmithkline fined £ 297m by chinese government over bribery scandal .
story to follow

documents.title: shell welcomes referendum result
text: and we have confirmation that the oil industry is relieved that the uncertainty - business 's perennial bugbear - is over .

royal dutch shell ceo , ben van beurden , says : shell welcomes the decision by the people of scotland to remain within the uk , which reduces the operating uncertainty for businesses based in scotland , '' `` shell will continue to work closely with both the uk and scottish governments to help the industry deliver vital energy supplies through investment in the uk 's oil and gas resources .
we look forward to continuing our proud association with scotland . ''

financial services group alliance trust has joined the ranks of scottish-based firms pledging not to move south : alliance trust says to continue to serve shareholders , customers from offices in dundee , edinburgh and london
the ftse 100 has disappointed those who expected an early surge following the no vote , up just 35 points or 0.5 % at the moment .
but it must be remembered the index is a global one , reflecting more than just uk concerns .
to illustrate that , the leading fallers in the index are mining companies , hit by falling metal prices on concerns about the outlook for china and the prospect for us interest rate rises .
nick fletcher has details here .

david cameron 's pledge this morning for more devolution of powers across the uk , not just to scotland , could have major implications for fiscal policy , suggests political editor , patrick wintour : patrick wintour ( @ patrickwintour ) on face of it , cameron has said tax will be english issue so scottish mps excluded from budget and scottish based mp can not be chancellor .
here 's patrick 's story on the pm 's statement this morning : david cameron commits to devolution revolution in uk after scotland vote
accountants at bdo are speculating that britain could soon have differential tax rates , if more powers are handed to scotland .
jill treanor ( @ jilltreanor ) tax experts at bdo point out that promises on devolution could lead to scottish businesses having different tax rates to rest of uk
guy harding ( @ guyhardingsky ) scotsie20 is broadly positive first thing !
rbs up 3.5 % # reliefrally # indyref
a trader at ig index looks at his screens , in central london september 19 , 2014 .
melville/reuters with the referendum officially won by the no side , the city is relatively calm .

my colleague simon goodley is on the trading floor of ig group , and reports : it 's far quieter here than it would have been if the yes campaign had won - but there are still big movements in share prices after the london stock exchange opened at 8am .
royal bank of scotland is up 3.5 % , while lloyds banking group and standard life are both up 2 % - as investors are relieved they wo n't have to relocate to london .
still , the city is all about zero sum gains .

alastair mccaig , ig 's chief market strategist , says : good news for rbs and lloyds is bad news for pickfords , which presumably wo n't be getting a large order to move executives from the banks south now . ''

in a wider basket of scottish-facing stocks , diageo - which derives a decent proportion of its business from scotch , is up 0.78 % , pump maker weir group has gained 2.15 % , while defence contractor bae systems , which is assembling aircraft carriers on the clyde , added 1 % .
also , ag barr , the maker of irn bru , has edged up 0.24 % , although apparently only around 40 % of its business is in scotland

my colleagues in scotland have launched a new liveblog covering all the developments following the independence referendum : scotland votes no in independence referendum - live coverage we 'll be tracking the financial , economic and business reaction here
business for scotland , which has pushed for a yes vote , is understandable disappointed by the referendum result , but determined to press on .
chairman tony banks says : huge credit due to the scottish people who have , by and large , conducted the biggest political debate there is with good grace , good manners and some sparkling wit .
the legacy of this campaign is a thoroughly politically engaged and active population the likes of which scotland has n't seen in my lifetime .
like others who campaigned for a yes vote , i 'll continue campaigning for a better scotland .
we wo n't have all the tools that we would have had after a yes vote but we 'll all do what we can to improve things as much as possible . ''

documents.title: spanish shares rise , bond yields ease
text: spain 's stock market is also rallying this morning , as the scottish result dents catalonia 's hopes of independence .
the ibex index of the 35 biggest companies on the madrid stock market is up by 156 points , or 1.5 % , to 11147 .
all but one share has gained ground .
steve collins ( @ tradedesk steve ) ibex up 1.7 % - spain rather more relieved than the uk about the scottish vote !
the interest rate , or yields , on spanish bonds has also fallen this morning .
that shows that investors see spanish debt as less riskier , even though catalonia 's parliament is pushing for an independence referendum of its own .
here 's nick fletcher 's opening market report highlighting how scottish=linked companies are leading the ftse 100 higher , albeit not as high as first predicted .
here 's the ftse 100 early risers , led by rbs : .
reuters
joshua raymond ( @ josh cityindex ) here 's a snapshot of the key stocks moving in the opening minute # ftse # rbhs # weir # lloyds
companies with scottish links have moved sharply higher in early trading as the stock market gave the thumbs up to the outcome of the referendum vote , write nick fletcher .

with the financial sector a key area for scotland , royal bank of scotland is leading the way and has risen 12.7p or 3.5 % to 369.9p , lloyds banking group is up 1.33p to 77.20p or 1.8 % , standard life has added 6.4p to 422.1p or 1.6 % .
sse is 48p higher at £ 15.69 while engineering group weir is up 68p at £ 26.98 .
babcock international is 35p better at £ 11 .
at the moment the ftse 100 is up 41 points or so , having failed to meet some of the more optimistic predictions .

documents.title: ftse 100 up 51 points at the open
text: the london stock market is open and the ftse 100 has jumped by 51 points , or 0.75 % , to 6870 in very early trading .
full details to follow

clydesdale bank has also announced that nothing 's going to change : jill treanor ( @ jilltreanor ) australian owner of clydesdale bank says `` business as usual '' and `` has strong roots in scotland ''

many ( but not all ) business chiefs had warned that independence could have pushed up costs and created painful uncertainty , so there is a collective sigh of relief across the business community '' this morning .
that 's the cbi 's take , anyway .

here 's john cridland , their director-general : business has always believed that the union is best for creating jobs , raising growth and improving living standards , and welcomes that the people of scotland want to play an integral role in this internationally successful partnership .

as the debate now moves to the question of further devolution , it is important that it does not undermine the strength of the single internal market and it is in the best interests of citizens living in england , wales and northern ireland , as well as those in scotland .
such a difficult campaign inevitably leaves scars which will take time to heal and we now need politicians , businesses and citizens to unite to achieve a better future for all in the uk .
now is also the time to rebuild relationships outside the uk to reassure international investors and other partners that we will emerge stronger and more confident in the months and years ahead . ''
mike van dulken ( @ accendo mike ) # ftse100 called +70pts at 6885 as markets prefer scotland the not so brave and prospect of looser global monetary policy for longer

documents.title: oil industry could be a winner
text: lawson/pa there will be a huge sense of relief around the north sea oil and gas industry that scotland have opted to remain part of the uk .
our energy editor terry macalister says : there is nothing companies fear more than political uncertainty given the average investment offshore is very large and the time scales very long .
a yes '' vote could have led to a protracted row over where exactly the boundary lay offshore between england and scotland < corrected > .
it would have also led to worries about different tax systems and even safety regulations north and south .
but the oil and gas industry may be a small winner out of the referendum .
it has often felt its financial contribution to the uk economy has been overlooked .
not now .
its value to the exchequor at least has been endlessly discussed and valued by politicians and economists .
the word on the trading floors is that shares in scottish-based firms like rbs will jump by at least 2 % in a few minutes .
ransquawk ( @ ransquawk ) following 'no ' vote : rbs ( rbs ln ) , lloyds ( lloy ln ) seen up 2-3 % , sse ( sse ln ) and weir group ( weir ln ) seen up 3 %
juliet samuel ( @ citysamuel ) standard life now keen on scotland again : `` we are proud of our scottish heritage and will continue to build our success from these roots . ''

documents.title: standard life : we 'll keep building on scottish roots
text: edinburgh-based standard life has issued a statement , saying it will consider the implications of any changes for our customers and other stakeholders in our business '' of future constitutional changes , following the referendum .
it has also pledged to keep building on its scottish roots , suggesting that it will not be moving operations out of scotland now .
standard life has already set up english subsidiaries '' in case of a yes victory .
here 's the full statement : update on scottish referendum result we fully respect the decision of the scottish people .
we recognise that further constitutional change is very likely following the clear result of the referendum .
we will consider the implications of any changes for our customers and other stakeholders in our business to ensure their interests are represented and protected .
as a large company based in scotland , standard life is ready to contribute to this process .
it is now important that we all move forward with respect and work together constructively in the best interests of scotland and the united kingdom .
standard life is a successful global company - we are proud of our scottish heritage and will continue to build our success from these roots .

the main impact of a no vote has probably already been factored into the stock market , according to tom stevenson of fidelity personal investing , but uk shares still look attractive in comparative terms .
he said : the ongoing uncertainty will provide something of a drag on the uk market in the weeks and months ahead but it comes against a relatively positive backdrop .
the london market has materially underperformed the us , for example , since the financial crisis and it now enjoys a significant valuation advantage over wall street .
in a low interest-rate environment , equity income will continue to be an attractive source of yield for investors .
with the ftse 100 yielding 3.5 % , large uk shares are reasonably well underpinned .
i would expect larger companies to outperform mid- and small-cap stocks in an uncertain environment , even if some of the more domestically-focused stocks enjoy a short-term bounce .
although bonds look less attractive than equities , due to their historically low yields , the increase in market uncertainty may increase the attraction of fixed income investments .
it is worth remembering that markets are global , especially internationally-focused markets like london .

they have shaken off massive geo-political uncertainty in ukraine and the middle east ; they have taken in their stride an imminent reversal in the interest rate cycle and the threat of deflation in europe ; i suspect they will also shrug off a close-run independence vote .

documents.title: rbs : we wo n't be moving head office out of scotland
text: the royal bank of scotland headquarters .
macleod royal bank of scotland has announced that it will certainly not be moving its head office out of edinburgh .
the contingency plan that was drawn up in case scotland voted for independence has been thrown in the bin .

rbs says : the announcement we made about moving our registered head office to england was part of a contingency plan to ensure certainty and stability for our customers , staff and shareholders should there be a 'yes ' vote .
that contingency plan is no longer required .
following the result it is business as usual for all our customers across the uk and rbs . ''

documents.title: lloyds : we 're committed to keeping a 'significant presence ' in scotland
text: lloyds banking group has declared that it is committed to maintaining a significant presence '' in scotland .
it says : the group is proud of its strong scottish heritage and is committed to having a significant presence in scotland .
we remain fully focused on supporting households and businesses in scotland as well as right across the rest of the uk . ''
lloyds , like several other financial institutions based in scotland , had previously said it would move its hq to london if voters chose independence .
jill treanor ( @ jilltreanor ) lloyds - `` we remain fully focused on supporting households and businesses in scotland as well as right across the rest of the uk . ''
we 're still expecting shares to surge when the london stock market opens , in an hour 's time .
spreadbetters are calling the ftse 100 up over 1 % , or 75 points .

capital spreads dealer jonathan sudaria says shares are set to surge out of the starting blocks '' , even though many city investors concluded yesterday that the no side would win : clients had spent yesterday steadily building up long positions in sterling and the ftse as they bet that cooler heads would prevail and the union would remain intact . ''
david cameron is trying to calm those fears over another vote in scotland .
he 's giving an official statement now , saying the matter has been settled for a generation .
full coverage in our liveblog .
juliet samuel ( @ citysamuel ) cameron : `` now the debate has been settled for a generation or , as alex salmond has said , perhaps for a life time .
no debates , no reruns . ''
martin gilbert , chief executive of aberdeen asset management , said uk investors would welcome a reduction in the uncertainty of recent months '' , writes nick fletcher .
the boss of scotland 's largest fund manager - who had tried to remain neutral during the campaign - said scotland could look forward to a prosperous future now the vote was over .
but both sides now needed to come together and move forward .

he said in a statement : scotland has long been a world leader in business sectors such as oil and gas , whisky and investment and the task now is to grow the rest of the economy with the strong support of politicians of all parties .

documents.title: bcc : businesses want to see a clear , fair , swift devolution settlement
text: john longworth , director general of the british chambers of commerce , is n't impressed by westminster 's handling of the independence vote .
speaking on bloomberg tv , he says : our politicians have not been great poker players in a high-stakes game .
longworth also warns that businesses are anxious that the issue of scotland 's place in the uk , and the powers held by politicians in holyrood , is resolved .
the people of scotland have spoken .
their historic decision to remain part of the united kingdom will be a relief to many businesspeople and a disappointment to others , but it was a decision for the scottish people alone to make .
the companies i speak to are clear that this can not simply be the first in a series of referenda , until one side or the other gets the result that it wants .
business and investment prospects across the uk would be deeply hurt by a quebec-style 'neverendum ' - a lesson that politicians must heed .
yet businesspeople all across the uk have long known that the referendum would be the start , rather than the end , of a process of change .
businesses will now expect westminster and holyrood to reach a devolution settlement that is clear , fair to both sides , and swiftly executed
joel hills ( @ itvjoel ) the anxiety about currency is over .
lloyds , rbs , standard life will remain registered in scotland .
contingency plans back on the shelf .
alan clarke , economist at scotiabank in london sends us his early reaction to the vote .

he sees implications for rate hike bets in the uk and in the very short term relief in financial markets.clarke says : all in all , the 'no ' outcome comes as a relief to the market , though there will be some residual fine tuning left to run once the dust settles .
the reduced uncertainty is likely to see the market bring forward the timing of the first boe rate hike again , though within reason .
inflation has been far lower than expect since the august inflation report .
depending on how the pound exchange rate moves in the coming days , this could lead to another downward revision to the bank 's inflation projection .
in turn that should prevent market expectations of a hike coming too far forward .
we still expect the first move to come in february .
on the longer-term , clarke reckons a second referendum is n't likely for at least a decade ( so get some sleep while you can ) .

while there is likely to be speculation that since it was such a close outcome , another referendum ca n't be far away , it is worth stressing that the snp pledged during the campaign not to have another poll for a generation .
when pressed on timing , the scottish first minister suggested that this meant around 20 years .
as a guide , there was a 15 year gap between the first quebec referendum and the re-run .

this removes a considerable amount of the uncertainty in the aftermath of the referendum , but there is plenty of unfinished business that will have to be hammered out in the coming weeks and months .
despite this morning 's results , the issue of scottish independence has n't vanished for ever , says bob parker , senior advisor at credit suisse .
speaking on bloomberg tv , he says : one has to recognise that it is the mandate of the snp to continue to argue for scottish independence they 're not going to change their spots .
but the 'biggest risk ' of the uk breaking up is off the table for at least two to three years '' , parker added .
with counting still going on , more than one and a half million votes have already been counted cast in favour of scotland being an independent country , and 1.9 million against .
our main scotland liveblog has all the details .
david bloom , head of foreign exchange strategy at hsbc , has been at his desk all night in canary wharf , my colleague jill treanor reports .

sterling had nerves of steel through the night , '' he said , pointing to the moment just before 11pm when pollster peter kellner , who runs yougov , said it was 99 % certain that it was a victory for no .

asia was open and then people got in super early as well , '' sterling could have slumped to $ 1.55 or even $ 1.50 if there had been a yes '' vote , bloom said , but at $ 1.64 it is trading at around the right levels .

berenberg bank 's rob wood also warns that there are a lot of unknowns '' swirling around the uk now , including its membership of the european union : that is the main point after a campaign in which london felt compelled to promise scotland more powers at virtually the last minute to break the pro-independence momentum .
what is certain is that the uk will change materially as a result of this referendum despite the no '' vote to independence .
the uncertainty over scotland 's position and over the position of the uk in europe will not go away .
the risks are worth watching carefully indeed .
the bank of england is not planning to make a statement following the referendum result , a spokesman says .

documents.title: iod : sighs of relief , but devolution questions remain
text: the institute of directors has struck a cautious note .
with the immediate question of scotland 's future is resolved , attention turns to the new powers that edinburgh was promised by westminster leaders in the final days of the campaign .

simon walker , director general of the institute of directors , says : there can be no doubt that many businesses will breathe a sigh of relief that the prospect of a contentious currency debate and prolonged economic negotiations have been avoided , and yet we know that significant changes are still on the cards .

the main party leaders have made clear their intention to devolve further power to the scottish parliament , and over time this will give the people of scotland more of a say over how to manage their economy .

as negotiations commence on a future settlement for scotland , the focus must be on ensuring that any new powers are used to boost scotland 's economic competitiveness , unleash enterprise and attract further investment .
we are now at the beginning of a national debate about economic devolution .
the scots started that debate , and now it 's time for all of us to contribute new ideas about how our nations , regions and cities are run for the benefit of the entire country . ''
the lights have been burning all night at the bank of england .
the governor , mark carney , had flown back from the g20 meeting in cairns , australia , in time for the referendum result .
he was in threadneedle street in the early hours of the morning in case a contingency plan was needed if there had been a yes vote .
that was n't needed , in the end , but it shows how the bank was ready to attempt to calm a market panic .
mark broad ( @ markabroad ) lights burning at @ twitterid .
sigh of relief from mark carney ?
some sleep having just got back from g20 in aust
the pound has gained ground against all major currencies this morning , as this chart shows : world first ( @ world first ) the currency question .
sterling higher against all g10 currencies since yesterday morning -
brenda kelly of ig index confirms that a relief rally is in the making in uk markets '' , driven by companies who would have faced disruption if scotland had chosen independence .
key areas to watch will be the banks such as rbs and lloyds , as well as big scottish firms like standard life , aberdeen asset management and weir group .
investors in these firms will be relieved that management will be able to devote their time to business performance , rather than fretting about contract changes or headquarters moves .
meanwhile , the capital flight from the pound and gilts should see a reversal too , thanks to the decision of scotland to remain with the 307-year old union .

documents.title: ftse 100 tipped to rise by over 1 %
text: shares in london are going to jump when trading begins , in two hours time .
the futures market suggests the ftse 100 index will leap by 1.2 % , or 80 points , to 6900 .
that would leave the blue-chip index just 50 points shy of its record high , set back in 1999 .

documents.title: pound surges as no side triumphs in scotland
text: many city workers came in especially early today , and some even worked all night , in case the referendum delivered a shock victory for the yes side .
but as the results came in , they pushed the pound higher as it became clear that the union was safe .
there was a surge of trading in the pound in the early hours of the morning , traders say .
the pound first jumped shortly after the polls closed , when yougov released a survey showing a win for the no side .
it continued to surge as early results confirmed this view , hitting a high of $ 1.6524 .
that 's a gain of more than one cent.. reuters mark broad ( @ markabroad ) sterling reacts to emerging no vote # indyref

documents.title: scottish referendum result cheers the markets
text: pro-union supporters celebrating as scottish independence referendum results are announced at a 'better together ' event in glasgow this morning .
buchanan/afp/getty images good morning .
relief is sweeping the financial markets after scotland voted to remain within the united kingdom .
the pound is rallying in the foreign exchange markets , hitting fresh two-week highs against the us dollar and new two-year highs against the euro .
shares are also expected to jump when trading begins in london in a couple of hours time .
after a nervy few weeks , and a dramatic night of results from scotland , investors will be quietly relieved that britain is staying together .
worries about currency unions , sterlingisation , and how britain 's national debt might be split can be put to one side .
i 'll be covering the financial reaction to a vote that has gripped the uk , and captured the attention of the world , and looking at the short and long-term consequences .

our main scottish election liveblog is here : scottish independence referendum : scotland votes no - live our latest story on the referendum is here : scotland rejects independence with no vote set for victory

S&P and Fitch say UK credit rating unaffected.
EC welcomes result as Spanish stocks jump.
